awd_titl_txt: MRI: Development of An Instrument for Secure Cyber Physical Systems Analytics
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to develop a secure and scalable instrument that can efficiently perform big data analytics on data collected from Internet of Things (IoT) devices while providing tools for preserving data security and privacy. IoT devices are monitoring and controlling systems that interact with the physical world by collecting, processing and transmitting data using the internet. IoT devices include home automation systems, smart grid, transportation systems, medical devices, building controls, manufacturing and industrial control systems. With the increase in deployment of IoT devices, the amount of data generated by these devices also increases.  There is thus a need for large-scale, and secure data processing systems to process and extract information for efficient and impactful decision-making. The issue of trustworthiness in computation and data security arises when the IoT data contains sensitive information. For example, data collected using the home health devices such as a wireless blood-pressure monitor may need to be analyzed and correlated with other information. In these cases, data owners may need to protect their data and demand guaranties about data security and integrity. Development of this instrument will enable new research projects that require efficient and secure processing of IoT data. Consequently, this may allow the creation of novel IoT data processing tools and services which are not feasible today due to security and privacy concerns. 

The proposed instrument will integrate two important components in a novel and unique way. First, an IoT data gathering component that can collect various data from IoT devices including the industrial IoT (IIoT) devices, will be developed. This component will create the necessary data gathering part of the instrument. It will allow researchers to adjust data collection frequency and granularity to enable different types of data collection activities for various research projects. The second component of the instrument will be the secure data analytics layer that can process the potentially sensitive IoT data including the network packets, sensor data, etc. As part of this component, recently developed secure data processing techniques which leverage trusted execution environments (TEEs) will be implemented. In addition, these TEE-based techniques will be tailored for different types of IoT data to increase their efficiency and limit any sensitive data leakage. During this project, these components will be integrated using custom developed software which will be open sourced at the final stage. Furthermore, these components will be integrated to test various research tools with respect to scalability, security and data privacy. The developed instrument will be made available to our collaborators and larger scientific community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Internet of Things (IoT) devices, which include home automation systems, smart grids, transportation systems, medical devices, and industrial control systems, function by monitoring, controlling, and interacting with the physical world through data collection, processing, and transmission using internet standards. As the deployment of IoT devices increases, so does the volume of data they generate, necessitating the development of large-scale, secure data processing systems for efficient and effective decision-making. This is especially pertinent when IoT data contains sensitive information, such as data from home health devices like wireless blood-pressure monitors, which may require secure analysis and correlation with other data. Owners of this data often need assurances regarding the security and integrity of their information.

This project was dedicated to creating a secure, scalable instrument capable of performing data analytics on IoT-generated data while ensuring data security and privacy. The development of this instrument could pave the way for new research initiatives requiring the efficient and secure processing of IoT data, potentially leading to innovative data processing tools and services that address current security and privacy limitations

The developed instrument uniquely integrates two critical components. The first is an IoT data gathering component designed to collect a wide range of data from IoT devices. This component forms the foundation for data acquisition within the instrument, offering researchers the flexibility to customize data collection frequency and granularity, catering to the diverse needs of various research projects.

The second key component is a secure data analytics layer, engineered to process potentially sensitive IoT data, including network packets and sensor data. This layer incorporates cutting-edge secure data processing methods that utilize Trusted Execution Environments (TEEs). TEEs provide a secure region within a processor, ensuring that sensitive code and data are stored, processed, and protected in an isolated and secure environment. Furthermore, these TEE-based techniques are specifically adapted for various types of IoT data to enhance their efficiency and minimize the risk of sensitive data exposure.

Our instrument, including an end-to-end secure IoT data management system, harnesses robust cryptographic methods and Trusted Execution Environments (TEEs) such as INTEL SGX and ARM TRUSTZONE. We have developed an IoT data processing framework that securely operates within the SGX enclave, automating the secure control and management of IoT devices. The instrument was tested in real-time with IoT data from actual smart devices in a practical smart home scenario. Our investigation revealed that, despite end-to-end encryption, sensitive IoT information could still be inferred with notable accuracy in SGX environments, highlighting the limitations of encryption-based TEE solutions in fully protecting private information. To address this, we developed countermeasures involving oblivious execution and data padding to conceal potential data leakages. Empirical evaluations of these defense strategies have shown promising results, significantly reducing the prediction accuracy of sensitive IoT data. This enhancement further strengthens the security of encryption-based TEE solutions, thereby ensuring both system security and data privacy.

The overall architecture of the instrument we developed is depicted in the figure attached herewith.
